paragraphs.text: %md # Prediction Flight Delays with Spark ML This notebook demonstrates how to use Apache Spark’s ML pipelines with a Random Forest Classifier to predict flight delays. For more information, see [this](https://mapr.com/ebook/getting-started-with-apache-spark-v2/) MapR Spark ebook.

msg.data:
Prediction Flight Delays with Spark ML

This notebook demonstrates how to use Apache Spark’s ML pipelines with a Random Forest Classifier to predict flight delays. For more information, see this MapR Spark ebook.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
## Data Exploration
For this tutorial, we'll be using data from http://www.transtats.bts.gov/DL_SelectFields.asp?Table_ID=236&DB_Short_Name=On-Time.
The CSV data has been cleaned and tranformed into a JSON file with the following format: 
{
    "id": "ATL_BOS_2018-01-01_DL_104",
    "fldate": "2018-01-01",
    "month": 1,
    "dofW": 1,
    "carrier": "DL",
    "src": "ATL",
    "dst": "BOS",
    "crsdephour": 9,
    "crsdeptime": 850,
    "depdelay": 0.0,
    "crsarrtime": 1116,
    "arrdelay": 0.0,
    "crselapsedtime": 146.0,
    "dist": 946.0
}

We use a Scala case class and Structype to define the schema, corresponding to a line in the JSON data file.

msg.data:
Data Exploration

For this tutorial, we’ll be using data from http://www.transtats.bts.gov/DL_SelectFields.asp?Table_ID=236&DB_Short_Name=On-Time.
The CSV data has been cleaned and tranformed into a JSON file with the following format:
{
“id”: “ATL_BOS_2018-01-01_DL_104”,
“fldate”: “2018-01-01”,
“month”: 1,
“dofW”: 1,
“carrier”: “DL”,
“src”: “ATL”,
“dst”: “BOS”,
“crsdephour”: 9,
“crsdeptime”: 850,
“depdelay”: 0.0,
“crsarrtime”: 1116,
“arrdelay”: 0.0,
“crselapsedtime”: 146.0,
“dist”: 946.0
}

We use a Scala case class and Structype to define the schema, corresponding to a line in the JSON data file.

paragraphs.title: Import needed packages
paragraphs.text:
%spark
import org.apache.spark._
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions._
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
import org.apache.spark.sql._
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.{StructType, StructField, StringType, IntegerType}

msg.data:
import org.apache.spark._
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions._
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
import org.apache.spark.sql._
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.{StructType, StructField, StringType, IntegerType}

paragraphs.title: Define Schema for JSON file data
paragraphs.text:
val schema = StructType(Array(
    StructField("id", StringType, true),
    StructField("fldate", StringType, true),
    StructField("month", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("dofW", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("carrier", StringType, true),
    StructField("src", StringType, true),
    StructField("dst", StringType, true),
    StructField("orig_dest", StringType, true),
    StructField("label", StringType, true),
    StructField("prediction", StringType, true),
    StructField("crsdephour", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("crsdeptime", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("depdelay", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("crsarrtime", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("arrdelay", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("crselapsedtime", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("dist", DoubleType, true)
  ))

msg.data: schema: org.apache.spark.sql.types.StructType = StructType(StructField(id,StringType,true), StructField(fldate,StringType,true), StructField(month,IntegerType,true), StructField(dofW,IntegerType,true), StructField(carrier,StringType,true), StructField(src,StringType,true), StructField(dst,StringType,true), StructField(orig_dest,StringType,true), StructField(label,StringType,true), StructField(prediction,StringType,true), StructField(crsdephour,IntegerType,true), StructField(crsdeptime,IntegerType,true), StructField(depdelay,DoubleType,true), StructField(crsarrtime,IntegerType,true), StructField(arrdelay,DoubleType,true), StructField(crselapsedtime,DoubleType,true), StructField(dist,DoubleType,true))

paragraphs.title: Read the data from JSON file into a Dataset of type Flight
paragraphs.text: var tableName: String = "/user/mapr/flighttable"

msg.data: tableName: String = /user/mapr/flighttable

paragraphs.title: Add origin_dest column  and display the first 20 rows
paragraphs.text:
import com.mapr.db._
import com.mapr.db.spark._
import com.mapr.db.spark.impl._
import com.mapr.db.spark.sql._

val spark: SparkSession = SparkSession.builder().appName("flightread").getOrCreate()
 
// load payment dataset from MapR-DB 
val df = spark.sparkSession.loadFromMapRDB(tableName, schema)

df.take(1)

%md
The describe() function performs summary statistics calculations on  numeric columns

paragraphs.title: Perform summary statistics  on selected columns
paragraphs.text: df.describe("dist", "crselapsedtime","depdelay", "arrdelay").show

%md
In the code below a Spark Bucketizer is used to split the dataset into delayed and not delayed flights with a 
delayed 0/1 column. Then the resulting total counts are displayed.

msg.data:
In the code below a Spark Bucketizer is used to split the dataset into delayed and not delayed flights with a
delayed 0/1 column. Then the resulting total counts are displayed.

paragraphs.title: Add Column for Delayed Flights and count
paragraphs.text: df.groupBy("src","dst","label","prediction").count.show

paragraphs.title: Register Dataset as a Temporary View in order to explore with SQL
paragraphs.text:
df.createOrReplaceTempView("flights")
spark.catalog.cacheTable("flights")

%md 
# Use Spark SQL to explore the dataset

msg.data: Use Spark SQL to explore the dataset

paragraphs.text:
%sql
select crsdephour, prediction, count(prediction) 
from flights group by crsdephour, prediction order by crsdephour

FROM flights 
GROUP BY src
ORDER BY avgdelay desc

paragraphs.text:
%md
Stratified Sampling
In order to ensure that our model is sensitive to the delayed samples we can put the two sample types on the same footing using stratified sampling. The DataFrames sampleBy() function does this when provided with fractions of each sample type to be returned. Here, we're keeping all instances of delayed, but downsampling the not delayed instances to 29%, then displaying the results

msg.data:
Stratified Sampling
In order to ensure that our model is sensitive to the delayed samples we can put the two sample types on the same footing using stratified sampling. The DataFrames sampleBy() function does this when provided with fractions of each sample type to be returned. Here, we’re keeping all instances of delayed, but downsampling the not delayed instances to 29%, then displaying the results

paragraphs.text: %md In order for the features to be used by a machine learning algorithm, they must be transformed and put into Feature Vectors, which are vectors of numbers representing the value for each feature. Spark ML provides a uniform set of high-level APIs built on top of DataFrames. We will use an ML Pipeline to pass the data through transformers in order to extract the features and an estimator to produce the model. Transformer: A Transformer is an algorithm which transforms one DataFrame into another DataFrame. We will use a transformer to get a DataFrame with a features vector column. Estimator: An Estimator is an algorithm which can be fit on a DataFrame to produce a Transformer. We will use a an estimator to train a model which can transform data to get predictions. Pipeline: A Pipeline chains multiple Transformers and Estimators together to specify a ML workflow.

msg.data:
In order for the features to be used by a machine learning algorithm, they must be transformed and put into Feature Vectors, which are vectors of numbers
representing the value for each feature.

Spark ML provides a uniform set of high-level APIs built on top of DataFrames. We will use an ML Pipeline to pass the data through transformers in order to extract the features and an estimator to produce the model.

Transformer: A Transformer is an algorithm which transforms one DataFrame into another DataFrame. We will use a transformer to get a DataFrame with a features vector column.
Estimator: An Estimator is an algorithm which can be fit on a DataFrame to produce a Transformer. We will use a an estimator to train a model which can transform data to get predictions.
Pipeline: A Pipeline chains multiple Transformers and Estimators together to specify a ML workflow.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Feature Extraction and Pipelining
The ML package needs the label and feature vector to be added as columns to the input dataframe. We set up a pipeline to pass the data through transformers in order to extract the features and label. 
A StringIndexer is used to to encode a string column to a column of number indices.
A Bucketizer is used to add a label of delayed 0/1. 
A VectorAssembler combines a given list of columns into a single feature vector column.

msg.data:
Feature Extraction and Pipelining

The ML package needs the label and feature vector to be added as columns to the input dataframe. We set up a pipeline to pass the data through transformers in order to extract the features and label.
A StringIndexer is used to to encode a string column to a column of number indices.
A Bucketizer is used to add a label of delayed 0/1.
A VectorAssembler combines a given list of columns into a single feature vector column.

## Setup Spark ML pipeline stages
Set up a pipeline to pass the data through transformers to extract the features and label, and pass this to a random forest estimator to fit the model

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Evaluate the model on a test set
The actual performance of the model can be determined using the test data set which has not been used for any training or cross-validation activities. We'll transform the test set with the model pipeline, which will map the features according to the same recipe.

msg.data:
Evaluate the model on a test set

The actual performance of the model can be determined using the test data set which has not been used for any training or cross-validation activities. We’ll transform the test set with the model pipeline, which will map the features according to the same recipe.

paragraphs.title: Get Predictions from Test data

msg.data: predictions: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [_id: string, dofW: int ... 22 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Accuracy is measured by the area under the ROC curve. The area measures the ability of the test to correctly classify true positives from false positives. A random predictor would have .5 accuracy. The closer the value is to 1 the better its predictions are.

msg.data: Accuracy is measured by the area under the ROC curve. The area measures the ability of the test to correctly classify true positives from false positives. A random predictor would have .5 accuracy. The closer the value is to 1 the better its predictions are.

paragraphs.title: Evaluate the predictions accuracy
paragraphs.text:
val areaUnderROC = evaluator.evaluate(predictions)
println("areaUnderROC "  + areaUnderROC)

msg.data:
areaUnderROC 0.6945482322554366
areaUnderROC: Double = 0.6945482322554366

paragraphs.title: Calculate some more metrics
paragraphs.text:
val lp = predictions.select( "label", "prediction")
val counttotal = predictions.count()
val correct = lp.filter($"label" === $"prediction").count()
val wrong = lp.filter(not($"label" === $"prediction")).count()
val truep =( lp.filter($"prediction" === 0.0).filter($"label" === $"prediction").count()) /counttotal.toDouble
val truen = (lp.filter($"prediction" === 1.0).filter($"label" === $"prediction").count())/counttotal.toDouble
val falsen = (lp.filter($"prediction" === 0.0).filter(not($"label" === $"prediction")).count())/counttotal.toDouble
val falsep = (lp.filter($"prediction" === 1.0).filter(not($"label" === $"prediction")).count())/counttotal.toDouble
val ratioWrong=wrong.toDouble/counttotal.toDouble
val ratioCorrect=correct.toDouble/counttotal.toDouble

val precision = truep / (truep + falsep)
val recall = truep / (truep + falsen)
val fmeasure = 2 * precision * recall / (precision + recall)

msg.data:
